justification: “We use the two predominant measures in mouse-tracking. The first is maximum absolute deviation (MAD)… The curvature of the mouse trajectory is interpreted as a ‘competitive pull’ … and used as a proxy for conflict.”
“The second is the area under the curve (AUC), the geometric area between the actual and the straight-line trajectory… Both measures are typically reported … to capture cognitive conflict.”
“In addition, we also use a more recent approach, prototypical classification… This method classifies trajectories into five prototypical trajectories associated with increasing levels of conflicts.”

“In addition to mouse movement, we also measure reaction time (RT)… RT is also considered a measure of cognitive conflict, with longer reaction times indicating greater difficulty in overcoming conflicting responses.”
